title.native: ルパン三世 ルパンvs複製人間
title.english: Lupin III: The Secret of Mamo

description:
Lupin, the master thief/spy/Jack of all Trades, has been executed, but he is still alive, and not even Lupin himself knows how that is possible. While trying to figure out, however, he and his gang are thrust into a conspiracy involving clones, Lupin's un-trustworthy rival Fujiko, and a miniature madman's plot to take over the world.

(Source: Anime News Network)
synonyms: Lupin III: Lupin vs The Human Clone
Edgar de la Cambriole : Le secret de Mamo
Lupin III: La pietra della saggezza
Lupin the Third: The Mystery of Mamo
Lupin III: O Segredo de Mamo

tags.name: Foreign
tags.description: Partly or completely set in a country outside the country of origin.

tags.name: Guns
tags.description: Prominently features the use of guns in combat.

tags.name: Clone
tags.description: Prominently features a character who is an artificial exact copy of another organism.

tags.name: Anti-Hero
tags.description: Features a protagonist who lacks conventional heroic attributes and may be considered a borderline villain.

tags.name: Fugitive
tags.description: Prominently features a character evading capture by an individual or organization.

tags.name: Police
tags.description: Centers around the life and activities of law enforcement officers.

tags.name: Crime
tags.description: Centers around unlawful activities punishable by the state or other authority.

tags.name: Primarily Adult Cast
tags.description: Main cast is mostly composed of characters above a high school age.

tags.name: Swordplay
tags.description: Prominently features the use of swords in combat.

tags.name: Nudity
tags.description: Features a character wearing no clothing or exposing intimate body parts.

tags.name: Samurai
tags.description: Prominently features warriors of medieval Japanese nobility bound by a code of honor.

tags.name: Body Horror
tags.description: Features characters who undergo horrific transformations or disfigurement, often to their own detriment.

node.description:
Monkey Punch is the pen name of mangaka Kazuhiko Katou, creator of the successful Japanese manga series [Lupin III](https://anilist.co/manga/30438/), which is still being animated to this day.

Influenced by [Osamu Tezuka](https://anilist.co/staff/96938/)'s works, he began to draw and moved to Tokyo in 1957 after graduating from high school. From 1959, he wrote for a publishing company specializing in rental books under the pen name "Kazuhiko Katou," while working on doujins with his younger brother, Teruhiko Katou, and another friend. After moving to Tokyo, he was influenced by the American parody magazine "MAD," and his style changed to an American comic book style. This caught the attention of Fumito Shimizu, editor-in-chief of Futabasha, and in 1966 he made his full-fledged debut with Playboy Nyuumon under the pen name Eiji Muta. Under the name of "Mania Group," it was made to look as if Senji Mashuu (摩周仙二) and Eiji Kirita (霧多永二) were participating, but in reality, Katou wrote the whole story by himself.

In 1966, under the orders of editor-in-chief Shimizu, he changed his pen name to Monkey Punch. Katou didn't like the name because it was given to a newcomer at random, and he planned to change it after about a year, but he couldn't change it because the work he published under this name the following year became a big hit.

In May 1967, he was selected to draw the cover art for "Zengan Manga Story Action Tokushuu-gou," which was published mainly for newcomers to "Manga Story," such as Baron Yoshimoto and Ken Tsukikage, and he continued to draw the cover art for "Shuukan Manga Action," a weekly seinen manga magazine that was newly launched in August with Shimizu as editor-in-chief. He also began serializing Lupin III under the title with the notation "Original by [Leblanc](https://anilist.co/staff/122907/)." in the August 10 first issue of Manga Action.

In addition to Lupin III, he has also created works such as Fukushuu Daikou, [Cinderella Boy](https://anilist.co/manga/71117/), and [MUSASHI: Gundou](https://anilist.co/anime/1200/). In 1996, he took on the challenge of directing an animated film with [Lupin III: Dead or Alive](https://anilist.co/anime/1416/).

He passed away due to pneumonia on April 11, 2019.

**Awards:**
- Inkpot Award
- Rome Comic Festival ROMICS Gold Award
- AMD Award for Merit
- Japan Cartoonists Association Award Minister of Education, Culture, Sports, Science and Technology Award

(Source: Wikipedia)

[Official Website](http://www.vap.co.jp/ohno/) | [Twitter](https://twitter.com/lupinjazz) | [Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/大野雄二)

Yuuji Oono is a Japanese jazz musician, composer and arranger.

He is known for his musical scoring of Japanese anime television series, particularly entries in the [Lupin III](https://anilist.co/anime/1412/) franchise. Most famously the 1977 series [Lupin III Part II](https://anilist.co/anime/1425/) and the noted [Miyazaki](https://anilist.co/staff/96870/) feature film titled [The Castle of Cagliostro](https://anilist.co/anime/1430/). Later anime series scored by Oono include [Shingu: Secret of the Stellar Wars](https://anilist.co/anime/1179/), the 1978 Toei series [Captain Future](https://anilist.co/anime/2561/) and the 1982 series [Space Adventure Cobra](https://anilist.co/anime/2451/). He has composed scores for live-action films, namely Toei's tokusatsu series Seiun Kamen Machineman, his only work on this genre to date.

Oono is also a member of a jazz trio with Czech bassist Miroslav Vitous and American drummer Lenny White, The Lupintic Five (later The Lupintic Six) and You & The Explosion Band.

(Source: Wikipedia)

Yukio Abe is a veteran art director that worked on creating visual concepts for later anime adaptations of Osamu Tezuka's manga.  Notably, he also worked with such anime directors as Masami Hata, the Dezaki brothers and character designer Sugino Akio.  Abe's works mostly consist of kodomo anime. His art style perfectly compliments children's stories creating beatiful, warm and fairy tale-like settings.

_Note: Not to be confused with the [audio engineer](https://anilist.co/staff/116191/)._

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/大塚康生) | [Wiki (en)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yasuo_Ōtsuka)

In 1956 Ootsuka saw an advertisement in Yomiuri Shinbun where [Toei](https://anilist.co/studio/18/) were asking for applications for animators. After passing the test Ootsuka worked with [Yasuji Mori](https://anilist.co/staff/103602/) and [Akira Daikubara](https://anilist.co/staff/131868/) on the [Tale of the White Serpent](https://anilist.co/anime/4513/) and learnt their approaches. Wanting to learn more animation theory, he began to seek out textbooks and was shown a textbook on US animation written by Preston Blair. After working on [Magic Boy](https://anilist.co/anime/4948/) in 1959 his animation of a skeleton was unintentionally considered comical due to its realism. This led to comical bad guy characters becoming Ootsuka's speciality.

Ootsuka believed that genuine realism doesn't suit animation and "constructed realism" is more suitable. [Hayao Miyazaki](https://anilist.co/staff/96870/) compared Ootsuka to Kenichi Enomoto, a Japanese comedian, in the use of this approach. After completion of his next film [The Wonderful World of Puss 'n Boots](https://anilist.co/anime/2279/) Ootsuka left Toei to join [Shin-Ei Animation](https://anilist.co/studio/247/), then A Production.

Ootsuka wrote several books about the anime industry. His Sakuga Asemamire is considered "a prime resource for the history of '60s and '70s anime."

In July 2002 an exhibition of his work and personal pieces was held in Ginza.

(Source: Wikipedia)
Produced and storyline writer of Robotech. Screenplay adaptation of many U. S. Releases of anime.

Yutaka Fujioka is the founder of [TMS Entertainment](https://anilist.co/studio/73/) (formerly known as [Tokyo Movie Shinsha](https://anilist.co/studio/65/) and also [Tokyo Movie](https://anilist.co/studio/6361/)/[TMS-Kyokuichi](https://anilist.co/studio/707/)), a Japanese animation studio originally established on October 22, 1946 as a textile manufacturer. He also founded the animation studio [Telecom Animation Film](https://anilist.co/studio/94/) in 1975.

He retired from the animation industry in 1991 due to the troubled production and commercial failure of [Little Nemo](https://anilist.co/anime/2286/Nemo/), which he took responsibility for.
Appeared in Star Wars: A New Hope as Commander Praji
Produced and storyline writer of Robotech. Screenplay adaptation of many U. S. Releases of anime.

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/吉川惣司)

A fan of [Osamu Tezuka](https://anilist.co/staff/96938/)'s works, when Yoshikawa was a sophomore in high school, he saw a "Mushi Production's first batch of animators wanted" news article and applied for the job, which led him to enter the anime industry. He was planning to go to art college, but was invited to join Mushi Pro, so he quit high school and joined the company. He participated as an animator for the first [Astro Boy](https://anilist.co/anime/2747/) series. In 1967, he participated in the founding of _Art Fresh with Gisaburou Sugii and Osamu Dezaki_. After working as an animator on Mushi Production's [Gokuu no Daibouken](https://anilist.co/anime/2687/), which Art Fresh participated in, he worked as a freelance animator before becoming a senior director and board member of Dyna-Method Inc.

In addition to serving as episode director, storyboard artist and writer, he also worked as a director. He has participated in [Tensai Bakabon](https://anilist.co/anime/6468/), [Star of the Giants](https://anilist.co/anime/5834/), [Ashita no Joe](https://anilist.co/anime/2402/), [Moomin](https://anilist.co/anime/8234/), [Lupin III](https://anilist.co/anime/1412/), [Invincible Super Man Zambot 3](https://anilist.co/anime/2200/), [Invincible Steel Man Daitarn 3](https://anilist.co/anime/3305/), and [Future Boy Conan](https://anilist.co/anime/302/).

In addition to anime, he created, wrote and directed Star Guardian with Airship Theater Company, wrote the screenplays for Tanoshii Moomin Ikka and Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs and wrote and directed The Wizard of Oz. It all started when he was asked by director [Masaaki Oosumi](https://anilist.co/staff/122102/) to help with the screenplay of Aladdin for Airship Theater Company's Aladdin when he was working on the TV adaptation of Moomin. In addition, he has worked on commercials, events, performances and novels. He has been a fan of science fiction since he read Shounen Shoujo Sekai Kagaku Bouken Zenshuu by Kodansha when he was a kid.

One of the reasons that the 100th episode of the [Kirby: Right Back at Ya!](https://anilist.co/anime/2390/) anime contained some problems, inconsistencies, and heavy-handedness in the plot and development is that Yoshikawa, who wrote the final episode, learned that his wife was in critical condition at the time and had to rush through the script and leave it in incomplete form in order to be present for her dying moments.

[Yasuo Ootsuka](https://anilist.co/staff/136873/) cited in an interview for the Lupin III Perfect Book: Complete Collector's Edition, that [Hayao Miyazaki](https://anilist.co/staff/96870/), [Isao Takahata](https://anilist.co/staff/100579/), Osamu Dezaki, and Yoshikawa as representative members of the Japanese anime world.

(Source: Wikipedia)
Previously the VP of Pioneer Entertainment and Geneon Entertainment, President of Animax of America.
Previously the VP of Pioneer Entertainment and Geneon Entertainment, President of Animax of America.

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/吉川惣司)

A fan of [Osamu Tezuka](https://anilist.co/staff/96938/)'s works, when Yoshikawa was a sophomore in high school, he saw a "Mushi Production's first batch of animators wanted" news article and applied for the job, which led him to enter the anime industry. (Source: Wikipedia)

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E9%9D%92%E6%9C%A8%E6%82%A0%E4%B8%89)

Yuuzou Aoki is a director, animator, screenwriter and storyboard artist.

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E9%9D%92%E6%9C%A8%E6%82%A0%E4%B8%89)
